confession.seduction_context: returning from visiting sick daughter-in-law at Staimbach, with whom she had watched all night. No motive suggested.

witnesses.name: Francois Farrant
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: wife's sister married to accused's husband's brother

testimony.quarrel_subject: wife reproached Jeanne and sister about their reputations on way to market, suggesting they should behave differently
dispute when Jeanne and husband walked through his meadow, and he gave them both a beating
son of Allois had accused his son of stealing shoelace and had beaten him; witness complained that if child was to be beaten that was for him to do
testimony.threat_quote: que sy Dieu luy faisoit la grace de vivre qu'elle le verroit sy bas qu'il ne scauroit que mectre avec son eaue

testimony.quarrel_subject: said that now her father was dead he would find out if he had done well; had been to law together, and it had cost him more than 40 gros

witnesses.name: Magdelaine femme Francois Farrant
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: wife's sister married to accused's husband's brother

testimony.quarrel_subject: reproached them with their reputations on way to market

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Insisted she was femme de bien, innocent of any witchcraft, even when confronted with Denisatte (wife of brother-in-law), who had accused her

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Still denied any crime, although threatened with torture. Then confronted again with Denisatte, who told her she knew very well that they had planned to kill Joliat's wife. Continued denials.

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Now started to confess. Had been seduced since marriage to Allois. Master called Ricqua; gave her herbs which she threw away. Agreed that she and Denisatte had plotted to kill Joliat's wife, but it was Denisatte who had given her bread to this end. Would not make any other confessions.

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Taken before justices of valley, now said that her confessions were untrue, and had been made from fear of torture. Now sentenced to be tortured.

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture. Said that previous day on way to Liepvre with other accused, la Grande Barbelline had said they must confess nothing, so she had revoked previous confessions. Racked multiple times before admitting malefices. Admitted hating Colas Jean Jacob, placing herbs where his animals must pass, causing loss of two cows. Agreed she had made Goury Maigrat ill with powder given her by her master.

timeline.subject: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
timeline.details: Formal death sentence, by burning alive

accomplices_named.name: Denisatte
accomplices_named.context: Wife of brother-in-law; accused Jeanne; allegedly plotted together to kill Joliat's wife; gave Jeanne bread to kill Joliat's wife

accomplices_named.name: la Grande Barbelline
accomplices_named.context: On way to Liepvre with other accused, told them they must confess nothing

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
notable_quotes.french: que sy Dieu luy faisoit la grace de vivre qu'elle le verroit sy bas qu'il ne scauroit que mectre avec son eaue
notable_quotes.english: that if God gave him the grace to live, she would see him so low that he would not know what to do with his water
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Nicolas Jean Jacob after dispute about beating his son

notable_quotes.speaker: wife of late Jean Joliat
notable_quotes.french: Jeanne, Jeanne, ne me veult tu poinct mectre hors de ce tourment
notable_quotes.english: Jeanne, Jeanne, won't you please take me out of this torment
notable_quotes.context: Called out to Jeanne while very ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeanne femme Alois Humbert
notable_quotes.french: Lainguy diable, lainguy par ta langue est tu ainsy
notable_quotes.english: Devil take you, is it through your tongue that you are thus
notable_quotes.context: Response to wife of Jean Joliat's plea

relationships.evidence_text: Francois Farrant and Magdelaine femme Francois Farrant
wife was sister to their husbands
Nicolas Jean Jacob and neighbour Colas Jean Jacob

economic_context.details: Marie femme Jean Joliat testified that Jeanne and her father had been to law together, and it had cost him more than 40 gros. Goury Maigrat had dispute when Jeanne and husband walked through his meadow. Lodger left Jeanne's house without paying costs.

harms_catalog.harm_description: legs became swollen, so that she could not walk
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: reproached them with their reputations on way to market at Ste Marie, suggesting they should behave differently; Jeanne was angry
Jeanne, her godmother, was angry because she had not wished her goodnight, calling her 'belle beste'. Had also been given some bread by Jeanne
overheard sisters talking about ways of killing cattle and damaging those they hated
lodger had left without paying costs
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: about 3 weeks later, when only stone's throw away

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill for a year, and one leg was still as if asleep
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute when Jeanne and husband walked through his meadow, and he gave them both a beating; she said he would repent

harms_catalog.harm_description: cows had not done well, and had brought him little profit

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: son of Allois had accused his son of stealing shoelace and had beaten him; witness complained; Jeanne threatened him
she hated him on account of la Joliatte
harms_catalog.method_alleged: herbs placed where his animals must pass over them (per confession)

harms_catalog.harm_description: legs became swollen, could not walk

material_culture.context: Jeanne gave bread to goddaughter Bablo; Denisatte gave Jeanne bread to kill Joliat's wife
Son of Allois accused Nicolas Jean Jacob's son of stealing shoelace
Master Ricqua gave her herbs which she threw away; later placed herbs where Colas Jean Jacob's animals must pass
Master gave her powder; used to make Goury Maigrat ill; gave powder to master when angry

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
Market where Magdelaine, Jeanne and sister were going when quarrel occurred; also where Jennon was going when she passed house
Where Jeanne's sick daughter-in-law lived; she had watched all night with her when seduced on return journey
Where Jeanne's husband went eating and drinking; residence of Marie femme Jean Joliat
Where accused were being taken when la Grande Barbelline told them to confess nothing
Jean de Barrois was working in his garden when sisters passed and he overheard them talking about killing cattle
Goury Maigrat's meadow that Jeanne and husband walked through, leading to dispute and beating
Where Catherine saw Jeanne and companion spinning late in the evening with faces very close

economic_hardship_indicators: legal dispute cost more than 40 gros
loss of animals worth 100 francs was significant hardship
religious_calendar_references: St Genais (offering made to cure illness)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jeanne and father of Marie femme Jean Joliat had been to law together, and it had cost him more than 40 gros

hearsay_chains.content: talking about ways of killing cattle, and of other ways of damaging those they hated
told him Jeanne, her godmother, was angry because she had not wished her goodnight

emotional_state_notes: insisted she was femme de bien, innocent
continued denials even when confronted with Denisatte
retracted confessions, saying they were made from fear of torture
unwilling to admit malefices even under torture initially

third_parties.name: Bablo
third_parties.context: Lost use of her limbs after Jeanne was angry she had not wished her goodnight; given bread by Jeanne

third_parties.name: wife of late Jean Joliat
third_parties.context: Was very ill; called out to Jeanne asking to be taken out of torment; Jeanne and Denisatte allegedly plotted to kill her

third_parties.name: Colas Jean Jacob
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: neighbor (hated on account of la Joliatte)
third_parties.relationship_to_witness: possibly related to witness 5 (Nicolas Jean Jacob)
third_parties.context: Jeanne confessed to placing herbs where his animals must pass, causing loss of two cows

third_parties.name: la Joliatte
third_parties.context: Source of conflict between Jeanne and Colas Jean Jacob

third_parties.name: barlier (lodger)
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: had been lodging in her house
third_parties.context: Left without paying costs; Jeanne threatened him and his horse broke its leg about 3 weeks later

third_parties.name: daughter-in-law at Staimbach
third_parties.context: Was sick; Jeanne visited and watched all night; seduced by devil on return journey

third_parties.name: son of Allois Humbert
third_parties.context: Accused Nicolas Jean Jacob's son of stealing shoelace and beat him, leading to quarrel

third_parties.name: son of Nicolas Jean Jacob
third_parties.context: Accused of stealing shoelace by son of Allois and beaten

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial shows pattern of accumulated grievances over multiple years. Witness testimony spans 2-6 years of alleged maleficia. Strong evidence of family/kinship networks involved (sisters-in-law relationship between accused and witnesses 1 and 8). Economic disputes prominent: legal costs, unpaid lodging, animal losses with stated economic value (100 francs). Confession extracted under repeated torture (racked multiple times). Retraction influenced by fellow accused (la Grande Barbelline). Notable that husband tried to restrain Jeanne during threat to lodger. References to healing through religious offerings (St Genais) by victims. Some uncertainty about relationship between Nicolas Jean Jacob (witness 5) and Colas Jean Jacob (victim in confession) - possibly same person or related. Identity of 'la Joliatte' unclear but appears central to Jeanne's stated hatred of Colas Jean Jacob. The phrase 'belle beste' appears to be an insult/sarcastic term.
